comments.commentBody: I like Will Shortz's approach less and less all the time.  The emphasis is all on the constructors showing off their cleverness for each other.  It's very in-clubby and off-putting.  I like good, complex puzzles, but I just find most of the recent ones irritating and not pleasurable.  How about having someone else take over and sending this self-congratulatory cadre off to entertain themselves.  They certainly aren't entertaining me.
Totally agree. Hoping Will Shorts reads these comments and takes them to heart.

Let's not throw the baby out with the bathwater.  Just recently we had a "constructor-centric" puzzle that was *also" a delight for solvers, as most who commented here agreed.  There are also plenty of weak puzzles that are not "clever constructor creations."  We've had a reasonably good run of reasonably good puzzles recently.  I found this one more exception than rule (or trend).

It seems to me that if the twittering continues after the inauguration, news outlets will have to decide how to deal with this. Does each sputter deserve the spotlight if this man never allows direct questions? The rush to interpret each 140 word dump represents much more thought than was given to the original.
And for the moment we have a President, with coherent thoughts.

trump is the rich version of chance the gardener

his simple incoherence was attributed deep meaning by people who did not want to be seen as unable to see the wisdom in his nonsensical blabbering
Twitter should delete his account for abuse - they should have done so 15 months ago.

I tend to read mostly older books that I never got around to in the past.

The two that spring to mind when asked for a recommendation from this year are: It Can't Happen Here by Sinclair Lewis and The Moneychangers by Upton Sinclair. Both politically relevant to our current time. The parallels are frightening and disturbing. History is repeating itself with slight twists. It helps to be informed and prepared for the worst of it.

A newer book I found profoundly moving was Voices from Chernobyl by Svetlana Alexeivitch. Also very disturbing but again crucial for our information and preparation. It can happen again.
Also: Philip Roth's "Plot Against America"

I've decided, as you did, to read the older books - either going back to favorites or reading those that have stood the test of time. I also am fed up with the new wave of books, which are confusing because there is no guiding plot line.  I might add to Kafka's "the meaning of life is that it ends" but it (i.e. reading) is easier if it has a beginning and a middle and an end).

Demockracy,
If I may put on my tin foil helmet for a minute you make one assumption that I don't agree with and that is what might seem accidental is not actually deliberate.
2500 years of Western Economic History tells us that the reaction to monetary and trade policies has not change since Solon forgave personal debt and Athens best and brightest were released from indentured servitude.

TN, you've it the nail on the head, the electoral college is antiquated.

Societies fail if the are unable to adapt. For much if its existence, the US has been the adaptable society above all others; but its political institutions have grown increasingly sclerotic. The popular vote loser was rarely elected President, but now it's happened twice in 16 years, this time by a grotesque margin, and it looks as if it could be getting built-in due population shifts.

Truth is a precious commodity, especially in these times.  At worst, this sort of discussion might be labeled pedantic, but it is not petty.  One of the unfortunate effects of this past election is that wild statements are being made both on the left (some by Krugman, unfortunately) and on the right where bigotry is fashionable, and our President-elect defines his own truths.  I would like to see more truth and more wonkish analysis in this blog.  In a time of unreason, we need rational voices.

"wild statements are being made both on the left (some by Krugman, unfortunately)"

Please provide an example of this. Fake balance is the same as being incorrect, and is used as disinformation

DR, Krugman does a fairly good job at defining his own truths.

His method is to set up a straw man, demolish it in style, and then claim that because he destroyed the giant, that his argument represents "the truth"...

And not just "the truth", but the immutable truth that he has managed to discover.

POMADE  gave me trouble since I kept thinking "fragrant dressing" must have something to do with salad dressing, not hair dressing. I read that the first pomades were made with lard or bear grease, so I guess they would have been fragrant rather quickly.

Is there nothing private equity won't invest in? Taking over essential services and then demanding ROI multiples leading to foreclosures gives a whole new meaning to the term culture capitalism.

There's plenty of blame here, mainly on the investment side. But it also sounds like local politicians were in way over their heads when reading the fine print about grounds for water rate freezes.

The privatization of America threatens to hollow out the poor and middle classes in everything from healthcare to tap water.

It almost sounds like a bad screenplay, except it's true, and growing more destructive for those who have no choice about bad decisions made by city politicians.

It's one thing for an individual to invest in a scheme, willing to take the risk. But quite another for an investment scheme to take over vital services, then price gouge citizens who have had no choice in the decision.

How could Bernanke push hard for fiscal policy other than stating clearly that whatever action the Federal Reserve took could not be a substitute for fiscal policy,
as he did on a number of occasions. The problem was never with the Fed, it took the only course available to it in the face of intense criticism. It is the Republicans in Congress that made it impossible to enact a sane fiscal policy and the blame should be put squarely on their shoulders.

and Elke (aka Robelke )
Printing out the puzzle, I saw the circles and so got out my crayons, expecting to have to connect them to get a fancy bauble or tree or such .
But then upon solving (with some difficulty) I saw that the theme answers were VISUALLY clever. Not so much when verbalized....
Appreciate the difficulty in construction and some cute clues, and don't want to be a PRISS about it, so will CLAM up now.
Buenos NOCHE (or something like that) et Jouyeux Fete .

Read this article well, and remember what Trump promised...public infrastructure upgrades by private entities, which will be given tax credits for doing so. Either way there is no free lunch, and if you go private, you'll pay more through taxes and/or user fees, because large shareholder profit and taxpayer subsidization for their tax credits, is a necessary part of the private contractor equation.

Honest and competent public entities and officials can do so, either with their own competent in-house public, or private experts, with competent public or private administration, contracting and financing to plan, build and/or rebuild the necessary public works.

Honesty and competence is necessary throughout the entire process, and remember taxation and user fees are still necessary, but ultimately they will be less onerous than using private business, again because of higher profit to do the same job.

And as far as procrastination, as one of my old docs once told me...see me now or see me later, but either way you'll see me, and later it will cost you more.

Finally, again, honesty and competence is the prerequisite for success, which is doable by the public sector.

You say "honesty and competence is the prerequisite for success, which is doable by the public sector".
Are you at all aware of the state of politics in our State of New York? I don't know if it's the water in New York, or the proximity of the center of finance to all that flows through politics here, but what you are in effect saying is, this approach to fix public infrastructure with private money cannot possibly work. The amount of money sloshing in and around government renders the viability of honest service a pipe dream, working its failures into theft of school funds, three card monte public contracts, peek a boo backroom lawmaking, and all manner of disservice to the taxpaying innocents. This is just another wrinkle for an increasingly desperate public hoping for a cure from a pie in the sky alliance between government agents looking to sell public assets, and finance privateers looking for good investments in the "public sector".

And then there is PRIVATIZATION per se and CORPORATIZATION.
They will eat us alive unless we fight.

While it took two terms and the bold policy initiatives on domestic and foreign policy fronts to claim legacy achievement by Obama, the President-elect Trump took only a brief transition interlude to signal the reversal of all that  which might isolate the US from the international mainstream.

Even the most correct explanation of the election results is not immediately consequential. What is urgent is a need to stop Trump now. His anti-commonwealth actions and governing choices show that he poises US political landscape to change abruptly and in the most anti-democratic way once he is in WH. Sadly, regardless of the political & economic consequences of the incoming changes he will be supported by enough populus in 4 years - many of his supporters will be fueled only by the racial hatred while many more will be gladly complacent or believe his lies about economy. Trump's lies are accepted as reality by his base that will not get educated overnight. Instead, he will continue feeding them with increasingly sophisticated fantasies that will cater to their worst instincts and hidden hopes. Indeed, "the worse the better" is a safe bet for Trump. A tradition of a Democratic Republic that we assume immutable, will be dismantled and made unrecoverable during his 1st year – much aided by the fuel lobby-controlled GOP & GOP-controlled judicial branch. Having lived in kleptocratic autocracy for the most of my life, this is what I see Trump brings to America. This country will then have to go through the major cataclysm - such as a nuclear war - to reset the stage for any possibility of a Democracy. I am not even mentioning environmental catastrophe that Trump’ll make "more likely than not."
Something needs to be done urgently, in the next 3 weeks, to stop the inevitable.

When I say economics is a cult not a science I am often asked to explain and I use a comment made I believe in the Krugman blog.
In response the someone questioning Western Economic Theory she wrote that thanks to computers we now had data and because of data we could now understand economics.
We wrote data before we wrote words. Our oldest known writing fragments are data. Prices, receipts, bills, weights and measures. We know the rents 3000 years ago but can only guess at the literature, values and beliefs. We have at our fingertips 2500 years of economic history to guide us into the future and we refuse to believe the past has anything to offer.
Somehow we have become a different species.

The cleverness is in the clues to the theme entries, but the answers are less than satisfying. I look at CLUTCH and CHINESE BOARD GAME and see two parts to the answer that have nothing to do with each (other than the last two letters of the first part overlap with the first two letters of the second). Yes, I see how the phrase "Grab and Go" suggests the two parts of the answers, but it feels like too small a pay-off.

SYMBOL FOR AMPERE is an essentially random answer for the "A" clue.
Trump tweets, the media cover it. That is what the media do. He is Peotus. They don't "enable" it.

Sorry to be so CRABBY today of all days, but I'm also puzzled by Deb's enthusiasm for the clues' telling us "how to marry" the two parts. Regardless of whether the parts are connected with "by," "plus," or "ahead of," the answer is always first part followed by second part.
leads to

And the in-the-language phrase with the 2-letter overlap?

Best I could come up with was PROPERNO[UN]LIKELY: 'Something next to impossible.

Am I repeating myself?

No, Leapy, you're not repeating yourself; you saying a different thing. So,

STRAIT[EN]GAGEMENT

Neatness leads to a meeting

Acqua is right, but not because this is about respect - because this is about meaning. The meaning of a recipe consists in two things: ingredients and method. Some recipes are more flexible than others - their identity is more vague or fluid - and some are very precise.

It's quite alright to take a traditional recipe in another direction, but after a point it becomes silly and pointless to claim it is the same recipe. So by all means experiment, but try to stay aware of what you're doing.

Lovely lesson in how to use LIMONs to make LIMONade.

Only, I'd say the correct RRN for Durham is NNE of CARY
Welcome to Durham, archeo-p! Hope you all have a Bright Leafy Christmas!!

In the Not-generally-available-to-the-solving-universe category, my ELDEST nephew was VP/counsel for Paramount Parks for decades, so VIACOM was easy-peasy at this location.

Take 'em where you can, friends.
Refining the AMBI objection: where BI means 'two', I consider AMBI to mean 'either'. It would be exceedingly unusual, as well as awkward, for an AMBIdextrous person to write using two hands.

It is a fact that different races metabolize different substances at different rates. Witness the "Asian flush" that comes with drinking alcohol. Many Asians have a variant form of the enzyme used to break down alcohol that causes the flush. African patients receive calcium channel blocker medications for blood pressure earlier than do Caucasian patients b/c they react better. We know certain types of cancers are found more often in certain subpopulations not just because of food, pollution, or lifestyle.

It stands to reason cancer treatments may affect all races differently. Diversity means better treatment, not just box checking!

ConEd is one of the most expensive utility company in the country and they hardly do anything their selves anymore. They just manage existing infrastructure and tack on a healthy bill for that service.

The stimulus package was an 800+ billion dollar gift to the public employee unions and stimulated and built nothing. Even Obama admitted there was no such thing as shovel ready jobs after he spent years lying about it.
